Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 01:00PM mthomp2020 wrote: If that's the only spot they found, and they were able to surgically remove it with clear margins, maybe they won't put you on chemo right away.   Since you're HER+, they could always just put you on Herceptin first and do regular scans to make sure it isn't cropping up elsewhere.  It sounds like it wasn't growing rapidly, so that's a good thing.  If you don't have any other lesions, I really can't see any reason to start chemo when you can use Herceptin.  If further scans show other lesions, then I could see doing chemo, but if they can't find anything else right now, why put you through chemo unless they have to?  I've been on just Herceptin with Zometa for about 9 months now myself, and my scans have been clean. Sorry you had to join us here.  This is a great group of women, and they'll help you every step of the way.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 11:25PM mthomp2020 wrote: Diane, rant away all you want - you have every right to! We fully understand. I'm so sorry to hear you're having so much trouble with the treatments. Is Navelbine making your neuropathy worse? If so, I can't blame you for wanting to take a chemo break for a while. Having to live that way can really suck all the joy out of your life. A lot of people don't realize how debilitating some of these chemos can be. It seems as if our oncs don't want to admit that this can happen. When you have children relying on you, you fight tooth and nail to be there for them. I think sometimes it's the only thing that keeps people going when it gets bad. I've got neuropathy in my hands and feet, moreso in my hands. It's at grade 2 right now. I'm on Navelbine, and it's causing more numbness. I live alone during the week as my hubby travels on his job. Plus he's legally blind and can't drive, so I'm the taxi driver. If I let it get to the point that I couldn't walk or drive, I wouldn't be able to live in my home anymore, and would have to go into assisted living. Since my hands are really affected, I'd assume that if I couldn't walk, I'd also lose a lot of use of my hands. I'd be giving up my pets, who are my "children", my home, being able to do the needlework I love doing, basically my life. So if it starts going in that direction, I'll stop treatment. My onc is the type who seems to value quantity of quality of life. One of the nurses even told me to make sure to emphasize to him that ending up in a nursing home is unacceptable.

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: Anyone here ever have a CT scan report say that you had a fatty liver? My last scan report did say that, and the doc that read it said the prior one also showed it, though the doc that read the previous one didn't mention it. Seems I have a different doc read my scans each time! Of course, my onc didn't mention it. When I saw him after scans, I hadn't picked up my scan copies from the hospital yet, so I didn't know about it. However, when the nurse hooked me up for tx, she said they were drawing blood for a metabolic panel. They had done that 2 weeks ago because I get Zometa, and their policy is to do a metabolic every time you get Zometa to make sure your kidney function is OK before you get it. So it kind of raised a red flag for me. Well, my blood work was good, so no problems so far. According to what I read, fatty liver is often caught by blood work. I'm both hypertensive, though under control, and hypothyroid, which both can be causes of it. They also drew blood for a panel yesterday, even though I wasn't getting Zometa, so it looks like my doc is keeping a close eye on it. Thing is, he never says anything about having any concerns. The only way I knew about it was reading my scan report. I guess there's a possibility that I'm getting liver mets again. I don't mind him being positive, but on the other hand he never really tells me much of anything. When he "goes over" my scans with me, he just says they're good, or when I had mets show up in my hip, that I had "some" progression in my hip. Good thing I read the reports myself. If it is fatty liver and not mets, I wonder what can be done about it. You need a healthy liver to process the chemo, so I don't want to end up with liver disease on top of everything else. Apparently statins are of no help. I'm on meds for my BP and thyroid. 　 Marsha Dx 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2010 07:49AM mthomp2020 wrote: Barbara, your website is wonderful.  Everyone on this board who's had a mastectomy without reconstruction should visit it. I just bought another Silique Comfort Lite on-line from Tru-Kare, and it was only $116 with shipping, which is even cheaper then TLC, which is still a good price in my opinion.l  I've also noticed that Amoena, I think, is selling them under their name at $300 plus.  I need to go to the fitter and get my freebie foob and bras.  I'll just use the foob for swimming.  I could probably get the form and bras that I really want from the fitter, but I'd have to pay for them up-front, and then apply to the insurance company myself for reimbursement for the difference.  By the time I've paid the mark-up the shop charges, I really wouldn't come out that much ahead compared to the on-line pricing, especially on the Comfort-Lite form.  The hassle just doesn't seem to be worth it.  There are only 2 "approved" providers in the area, and one of them only carries Classique forms and bras, so not a lot of choice there. It is pretty funny that a fitter tells a person who's an A that they need the weight or they'll develop posture/spine problems!  Until I got the Comfort-lite, my size 4 Airway light form would pull my bra down on that side so I would be a low-rider!  With the Silique, I don't have that problem all, plus I'm not getting wet under the form. So far, I haven't noticed any posture/back problems.  I ride my horse wearing a foam form, or none during the winter, and she certainly doesn't seem to notice the weight difference!  It's all about marketing/profit, isn't it?

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2010 02:44AM - edited Apr 23, 2010 02:49AM by mthomp2020 Otter, I'm using bra extenders for some of the same reasons.  I found them at Kohl's, and they carry all 3 sizes.  They're made by Maidenform.  I think they also carry them at Target.  They're 1 1/4" and 1 1/2"  with 2 hooks, and a 3-hook size.  Just measure your bra straps and see what size you'll need.  I only have 2-hook bras.  They really do help with the tightness problem.  I would think that anywhere they sell Maidenform bras would carry them.  They come 3 to a pack in white, nude and black, so you can cover all your color bases with one set. I still get puffy under my arm if I wear a bra all day, and it does get irritated, and I'm over 2 years out from surgery.  The mx bras were pretty uncomfortable for me under the arm.  I've never really been comfortable with the elastic anyway, and never liked bras.  I'm a large A/small B as well, so I know how you feel! Actually, I just got a couple of T-shirt bras from Nicola Jane in the UK, they're actually the Nicola Jane brand, and they're the only bras I've had so far that I don't want to rip off when I get home!  Plus they come with 2 sets of straps, one clear, and you can wear them as cross-over or I guess even as a halter bra.  And they're not super expensive.  One of the ones I ordered has a lace panel between the cups in the middle, so I can wear it with some lower tops.  They tend to run a little tight, so they recommended ordering up a band size and down a cup size.  Diagnosis: 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+

Posts.Content: May 14, 2008 12:00PM mthomp2020 wrote: Ah yes, the lovely gift of Taxol/Abraxane!  I had 6 Taxol tx's, and I do have neuropathy in my hands in the form of numbness.  I never did get the tingling, though.  My onc did prescribe Neurontin and it did seem to keep me from getting the tingling and pain, but it didn't prevent the numbness. Here's a website that has some information on different protocols for neuropathy that have been used with some success:  http://breastcancer.evidencewatch.com.  They cite a study using Acetyl-L-Carnitine that showed very good results in cancer patients using Taxol or cisplatin.  I'll be using that next time I get a neuropathy inducing chemo. Also, Dana Farber has a specific protocol they have for peripheral neuropathy help which is very useful.  I was using 30 grams of L-Glutamine a day and 600 mg of B6.  Both may have helped with the pain aspect, as I didn't have problems with nerve pain, just joint pain.

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2007 08:50AM - edited Oct 24, 2007 08:51AM by mthomp2020 A friend of mine had a hysterectomy done the same way, and her recovery was  very fast, especially compared with the other way of doing it.  She was back riding her horse 2 weeks afterward, so the recovery from that is faster then from a mastectomy.  I ride as well, and my surgeon had me wait 6 weeks.  It's great that they can do hysterectomies without going through the abdomen.  It greatly increases the recovery time, and it's certainly got to be a lot less painful. Good luck tomorrow.  I had my mastectomy in August.  I'm glad to say that I really didn't have any pain from it, just soreness under my arm from the lymph nodes.  Find out if they're going to use something called On-Q for the incision.  It's a little pump that feeds local anesthetic continuosly through a small catheter that runs along the incision.  Mine lasted for 60 hours.  I had absolutely no incision pain, and didn't need pain meds afterwards.  The Best Invention Ever!

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2010 07:54AM mthomp2020 wrote: I initially had 5 mets on my spine when diagnosed.  The bone scan only showed 3 areas.  2 spots were close together so showed up as one area.  The other spot that didn't show was an osteolytic lesion, the others were sclerotic.  So bone scans really only show the sclerotic lesions.  The lytic lesion was found on the CT scan done at the same time.  I've never had a PET scan or MRI.  The bone scan shows bone remodeling, areas where new bone is being laid down.  Breaks will show up as they heal, as new bone is being put down.  The sclerotic lesions are less likely to cause fractures then lytic lesions, according to my onc, and that makes sense.  I was thrown by my horse last year at Thanksgiving, and broke 4 ribs, but didn't damage any of my healed lesions, or the active lesions in my hip.  Sounds like the Zometa is working!

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: Got my scans done last Wednesday, and had a tx today, when I expected to get the results.  However, since I was just doing Herceptin, I didn't see the dr. and didn't get the results, so I ran by the hospital after tx and picked up a CD of the scans.  I've been on Navelbine since March, when scans showed mets in my right hip and on one rib.  Nothing in the liver, which initially 2 years ago had been full of spots.  None of my old bone mets are active.  The bone scan showed no change in my hip, so stable.  There was no sign of the spot on the rib, so probably trauma rather then met, though I certainly don't remember doing anything to my ribs!  I was really afraid there'd be some new activity, as it seemed they took some extra views on the bone scan.  So it looks like Navelbine is working.  In another 3 months, hopefully it'll show healing.  It does seem to take quite a while before that starts to show up on the scans.  Did mention that I have a small hiatal hernia, but it's not giving me any issues, so no big deal. I'm quite relieved.  Navelbine has been very easy to tolerate so far, though it has made my hands and feet number.  Hopefully another 10 tx's will knock those nasty suckers down in my hip!  In the meantime, I'm more then happy to have an affair with the stable boy! Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 03:20PM - edited Jun 15, 2009 03:23PM by mthomp2020 I have had some arthritis in my left hip, not that I've ever seen a dr. about it.  I took a liquid joint supplement, and it pretty well got rid of any issues.  Never really had a problem in the right hip.  The mets there have never bothered me at all, and they're around the socket.  Guess I have a high pain threshold!  I did have a lot of pain in both hips after my last Taxol tx in March a year ago, but that did fade away over time.  Bone scans were clean.  Funny thing is, I had really bad right hip pain on the Saturday and Sunday in March before my bone scan on Monday that found them, but the day of the scan it was fine.  I remember thinking that if it didn't get better, I'd have it checked out.  I hadn't had any problems prior to that, and none since.  Still kind of makes me wonder if it's mets or something else.  Now to go on for another 3 months before my next scans.  Hopefully by then it'll show some healing.  That's the big problem with bone mets - it takes a lot of time to see any results.  I guess no progression is about the only sign that chemo is working, but I'll take it!  With the liver mets, I saw results within 3 weeks of starting chemo - my onc was impatient and wanted to see if it was working!

Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 05:57AM - edited May 21, 2012 05:58AM by mthomp2020 I've done both, and of the 2 Navelbine was the easiest for me.  Neither one was bad, though.  If you worked through Taxotere/Carbo, there shouldn't be a problem working with either one.  I was on each one for 1 1/2 years. Navelbine can mess with your counts, but they can adjust the dose.  You have to watch out for constipation - it's not nicknamed Navelbind for nothing!  I had 2 dosage drops, then was fine after that. Gemzar can be especially hard on your platelets.  My counts stayed high enough that I never had a dose reduction or change of schedule, but many people do.  Over the last several months on it, I started having some problems with vomiting on the third and fourth day after tx, but no nausea at all.  My onc prescribed Regulan, and that really helped take care of the problem. Both cause hair thinning, but not total hair loss.  I had more thinning on Gemzar. Unfortunately, Gemzar stopped working, and I'm now on an old combo, CMF (cytoxan, methotrexate, 5FU), which is kicking my butt.  I had my first dose last Monday, and felt like crap on Tuesday, and have run a fever each day.  I've been able to eat breakfast and lunch, but by dinner the fever kicks in and I don't eat more then a few bites.  Ensure is my friend!  I go back today for them to check my blood counts to see if I need Neulasta.  Fortunately, tx is only every 3 weeks.  Hopefully, whichever one you choose will be gentle and easy on you.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2010 08:33AM mthomp2020 wrote: If you have bone-only mets, and only on your clavicle, then that would be a very low tumor load.  If you're hormone positive, then you could go on either tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor.  These days, most oncs will try anti-hormonals first for stage 4, especially with such a small tumor load.  I understand the AI's do have their drawbacks, but they can be extremely effective, as several other women here can attest to.  I'm not ER/PR positive, so AI's aren't an option for me.  However, I really didn't have a rough time on chemo, and pretty much did everything I normally did.  I've been on my current chemo now for over a year, and it really hasn't interfered with anything I normally do.

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2009 11:16PM - edited Aug 29, 2009 11:17PM by mthomp2020 I'd definitely get the liver mets biopsied.  I'm HER2+, ER/PR -.  I was stage IV from the get-go too, with extensive liver mets and several spinal bone mets.  When I finished A/C, and did Taxol/Herceptin, it wiped my numerous liver tumors out, and my bone mets were healed.  I was NED in March 08.  March 09, scans showed a new area on my hip bone, but my liver is still clean.  That actually surprised me, because I expected the liver to act up again first. I have scans again on Monday, so we'll see how that goes.  If you're now HER2+, Herceptin can be miraculous, so definitely insist on another biopsy. It's not that uncommon for new mets to test positive.  This effin' disease can take so many twists and turns.  I'll keep my fingers crossed that your next treatment puts you into NED status again!

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2010 07:05AM mthomp2020 wrote: I've heard complaints about trials being unable to find enough stage IV bc patients willing to enroll in their trials.  So many of these trials are so restrictive, however.  I've looked at trial requirements for trials for HER2+ that would interest me, but I can't qualify for them.  At this time, I have bone mets only, and very few trials allow participation if you only have bone mets.  And those trials that allow bone only disease end up having other restrictions that disqualify me.  I'm on a beta-blocker for high blood pressure, though I'm on the lowest dose.  One of the trials I looked at would disqualify me because of that.  One other trial disqualifies you if you're on thyroid medication for hypothyroid, which I am.  So that effectively disqualifies me from the trials I'm interested in. I'm fortunate that I've responded to the 3 chemo regimens I've received so far.  The first 2 I had a complete response to and was NED for a year.  The current one has kept me stable now for a little over a year.

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2008 07:12AM mthomp2020 wrote: The oncology center I go to is quite large, with several oncologists on staff, so they're very busy.  Their patient education consists of handing out 1 or 2 page flyers for each chemo/treatment you receive listing possible side effects.  To be honest, I'm more knowledgeable about side effects and things you can do to help alleviate them then my doctor and the nurses.  I've done my own research all along, otherwise I'd have been a bit lost.  I think there's a real need for a large practice to have someone who can do on-line research and who can spend one-on-one time with patients who have questions.  That person wouldn't need to have a medical degree, they would just need to be good at doing on-line research.  It would be such a huge help to patients.  Another helpful thing they could do is to give a list of good, supportive websites, such as this one.  I think it would make all the difference for many people going through this.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2010 08:56AM - edited Jan 27, 2010 08:58AM by mthomp2020 I've read that quinine does help with restless leg and muscle cramps.  When I was doing Taxol, I remember that one of the handouts they gave me for the chemo mentioned using tonic water for the muscle/nerve issues in your legs.  Tonic water contains quinine at a level that isn't going to harm you.  You can buy it at any grocery store in the soft drink aisle.  Canada Dry and Schweppes make regular and diet versions, and there's usually a store brand as well.  I like to drink it instead of soda since it's not sweet, and doesn't have caffeine in it.  And of course you can always add a dash of vodka or gin to it!  I just like it straight on the rocks with a dash of lime, though.

Navelbine was very easy for me, mainly occassional constipation and hair thinning.  I had one dose reduction for low WBC, and one because of gastric issues, but that's it.  It kept the bone mets pretty much stable, though there was no regression during that time.  I haven't had Doxil (I think it's the liposomal encased version of Adriamyacin), but I know some of the other women have had it or are on it, so I'm sure you'll be hearing from them shortly.

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2009 12:49AM mthomp2020 wrote: I was diagnosed with BC from the breast biopsy.  I had chemo first before surgery, and they did scans the same week they started my tx.  Scans came back showing liver and bone mets.  They biopsied the liver to make sure it was bc and not liver cancer.  They didn't actually check the status on the liver biopsy.  They had trouble getting a good sample as it was, since I already had cell death from my first treatment, which made getting a good biopsy difficult.  The bone mets weren't biopsied.  So I was Stage IV from the get go.  I think it's very unusual for hormone negative bc to change to positive, but who knows.  I guess at some future progression, it might be good to recheck the status if they can biopsy something easily.  The big issue might be going from HER2+ to HER2-, which does happen.

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: I had my scans this past Monday.  Over the weekend, my right hip was killing me, it was hard to walk down the stairs, get up and down from chairs.  By Monday it was back to normal.  It hadn't been bothering me prior to that, just the usual stiffness from arthritis, which prior bone scans mentioned some degenerative changes in that hip.  So I was very interested in seeing what the scan said.  When the tech got started with the whole body part of the bone scan, she asked me if I'd fallen, which I hadn't.  She also took some extra shots of my hips, so I figured something was up. I picked up a copy of the scans yesterday (which was my birthday, by the way).  I checked the bone scan first, and there was a large area around the right hip that I had no problem seeing.  There was also a small spot on a rib that was mentioned.  What a wonderful birthday present, huh?  The area involved is the socket.  I would think that, from the area involved, that I would be having a great deal of pain if it was mets.  Since last weekend, it hasn't bothered me since.  I own a horse and ride several days a week.  I rode last Friday.  When I dismount, I kick my feet out of the stirrups and drop to the ground.  I wonder if I could have done something when I did that.  The doc who read the bone scan suggested an MRI to get a better idea what's going on.  I don't see my onc until Monday.  To be honest, I even wonder if they read the report until the day of my appointment, since he's only at that office on Mondays, and my records are all kept at the office I go to.  My CT scans were fine, so nothing going on anywhere else.  The rib spot didn't show on the CT, which all my bone mets usually do.  There wasn't a mention on the CT scan report, it said no evidence of boney metastisis. Needless to say, I took an Ativan before I went to bed last night!  I'm afraid I won't be dancing with NED again for a while.  I'm really hoping the hip isn't mets, since it hasn't been bothering me.  I would think it would have been giving me a lot of trouble from the looks of it.  I'd like to get some more diagnostics done before we jump on the chemo/radiation bandwagon.  Now we'll just have to see on Monday what they tell me compared to what I read on the report.  I'll actually be seeing the NP, who actually gives me more info and answers my questions better then my onc.  I don't think I've ever talked to my onc more then 15 minutes, and that was my first appointment.  I think maybe I had 5 minutes, 10 tops, when he told me I was Stage IV.  Might be time to start looking for another onc who's more communicative.  Marsha Dx 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Scanxiety time mthomp2020 Times3

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2009 03:09PM mthomp2020 wrote: I'm definitely keeping my fingers crossed that it's something else.  Before they jump on the mets/chemo wagon,  I want at least some xrays to make sure I didn't do some other damage.  The doc that read the scan did suggest they have an MRI done to see what's going on.  The first time they did the bone/CT scans, my CT scans showed more bone mets then my bone scan did.  They saw everything on the CT that showed on the bone scan, plus a few more.  This time, the doc reading the CT scan reported no evidence of boney metastisis on the CT, but the doc reading the bone scan reported there was evidence on the CT, so who knows.  I just want to jump on this so I don't damage my hip.  I definitely don't need a fracture right now!  Funny thing is, I wouldn't have had a bone scan this time, just the CT, if I hadn't noticed that they didn't order it.  I had to call the office and tell them they didn't order the bone scan.  Considering my original bone mets were in my spine, I definitely want to keep a close eye on that and catch anything ASAP before it has a chance to do a lot of damage. I may just look into a new onc.  I did get the name of one who's supposed to be very good, and doesn't sugar-coat things.  He actually gave a lecture on living with stage IV breast cancer with our local American Cancer Society.  Biggest issue is his office is quite a bit further away, and if you have to go during rush hour, it can take forever to get there.  I drive myself to my appointments and don't take anyone with me.  I'll see what happens on Monday and come to some kind of decision. You guys are the best!  My hope is that I did do something when I hopped off my horse on Friday, since it started hurting the next day.  It feels just fine today, too, has since Monday.  Hey, on the plus side, I just turned 56, which means I'll no longer have to fill out the "are you pregnant" forms when I get my scans!  Yipee!

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2011 06:55AM mthomp2020 wrote: As 3katz said, if the lesions are sclerotic/blastic, they're less likely to break.  My right hip socket really lit up on the bone scan - I always said I wondered why it didn't hurt!  I continued to ride my horse with no problems.  Unfortunately, my L-3 has been damaged by a lytic lesion, and I had to give up riding.  Since it's compressing a nerve, I find even walking difficult at times.  If your lesions are all osteoblastic, you should be able to be active.  I found I didn't get any pain from the lesions, and I really still don't, so I guess the Zometa is doing it's job.  Doesn't help with the nerve compression though.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 03:21PM mthomp2020 wrote: Ouch - another sorry about the tooth!  I had a tooth that had a total of 3 crowns, a root canal and finally pulled it - fortunately, before I started Zometa!  My dentist seemed to think that the really big thing about teeth and biphosphinates is to avoid infection at all costs.  I had a crown done while on Zometa with no problem, and have my teeth cleaned twice a year.  Preventative maintenance, don't ya know!  I think one reason I had a problem with the tooth that was pulled was because I was grinding my teeth, especially at night.  I now have a partial guard that covers the top 4 teeth and wear it at night, and haven't had problems since.  It keeps me from putting pressure on the molars. Great news about the bone mets, not so great about the disc.  It seems to me that bone mets respond best to anti-hormonals rather then chemo.  If I end up having surgery for my spine met at some point, I'm definitely going to have them biopsy and test to see if I'm ER+ now.  Studies are showing that Herceptin can kick people to ER+ in about 30% of cases.  One more tool in the arsenal!

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: Went for my evaluation today for my leg. I'll be going 3 times a week for MLD only, no wrapping. I think she feels that since I'm unable to do the wrapping myself due to not being able to reach my foot because of the tumor on my spine, and having no one there during the week to help me, she'll try to use MLD only to bring the swelling down. I'm to do the MLD myself at home 3 times a day. I won't be able to do my foot and lower leg, just from the knee up. She's planning on doing 4 weeks of this. My insurance has only approved 12 visits. If it looks like it'll take more, we'll have to appeal, and possibly end up going a week without the therapy. I hope this does the job. She is LANA certified, and works through a hospital physical therapy department. It sort of worries me that I won't be wrapped, since that's supposed to keep your leg from swelling back up after the MLD. I guess I'll have to wait and see. I wasn't as swollen today as I sometimes am, and even so the leg was noticeably larger. She thinks we'll be able to bring it down with the therapy. At one point, my upper thigh was 2 inches larger then the other leg. I wonder if anyone else has had a therapist do MLD only with no wrapping, and if it worked for them. I'd hate to put in all this time and not have it take care of the swelling. Each session is 1 1/2 hours, so pretty time consuming. Marsha Dx 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2010 12:34PM mthomp2020 wrote: Janis, I've often thought you could have lesions that are different from each other, especially if you're both HER2+ and hormone +. The Herceptin/TDM1 would kill off the positive buggers, but not the non-positive ones, allowing the hormone-fed ones to grow. The only way to prove this would be to biopsy several lesions, and nobody really wants to do that. I was only 1% ER+ when initially tested. Some studies going on are showing that 1/3 of HER2+/ER- women become ER+ afer being treated with Herceptin. So it's possible that some hormone positive lesions could develop that aren't HER2+, but that's just my theory - I like to play doctor too! Since my liver was cleared of lesions, and my original bone mets healed, I've only had lesions show up in my right hip. They've been stable with Navelbine/herceptin, but they aren't healing either. If it wasn't too traumatic to get a sample from my hip socket, I'd ask for a biopsy, but that wouldn't be very pleasant. I wonder if the hip mets are ER+ now, and would respond to AI's. Bone mets seem to respond better to AI's then chemo.. Are you not allowed to add AI's to the trial chemo you're doing? It would be interesting to see if adding one has any affect on the one met or not. Then again, it might not even actually be a met but something else. You don't really know for sure unless they biopsied it. I'm glad they didn't kick you out of the trial yet. It's obvious it's working for you.

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 03:32PM mthomp2020 wrote: I think early detection is very important regarding bone mets.  Much better to catch those early before too much bone is destroyed.  I don't think waiting until you break something is the best time for them to check for mets.  I've been getting scans every 3 months.  I actually ended up going 5 months since my scans in October, and those were all clear.  For some reason, my onc didn't order them again until March, and then he only ordered the CT scan, no bone scan.  I called and got that straightened out, and good thing, since the bone scan showed a lot of activity in my right hip, plus a spot on a rib.  If this had gone another 3 months without catching it, I very well could have broken my hip.  I wasn't having any pain from it, outside of my normal arthritis stuff.

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 11:24AM mthomp2020 wrote: I went out and spent $200 on a wig before I lost my hair, it was a very nice looking Raquel Welch wig.  Never wore it, not even once!  I'd put it on for 5 minutes, and have to take it off.  I lost my hair right at the beginning of last summer, so that certainly didn't help things.  Plus I was having hot flashes.  I was peri-menopausal and having flashes already, and the chemo kicked things up a bit, to say the least!  I got very used to wearing just hats and scarves.  If I got too hot, I could take them off and cool down fast.  At home and with friends and family, I never wore anything.  To be honest, I never cried when I lost my hair, and I didn't think I looked all that bad without my hair - no worse then I did with it!  I hated my hair anyway, was just too chicken to do anything drastic.  I went from past shoulder length to bald - well, I never lost 100% of my hair, I did have some peach fuzz/stubble after I shaved it. I'm enjoying having short hair now - so easy to take care of it, no fuss and bother, just the ocassional hair cut.  Hey, if anyone's interested, I have a Raquel Welch wig that's a layered, below shoulder length in an auburn shade.  Definitely won't be wearing it!  Might just donate it to the local ACS.  No need for it to collect dust!

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 11:28AM - edited Apr 11, 2008 11:39AM by mthomp2020 Has your onc discussed other treatments with you?  The neuropathy can get pretty serious if it interferes with your mobility.  If you get to the point that you can't get around, or use your hands to take care of daily self-care chores, you'll need to have someone around all the time to help you.  Is he/she considering stopping it at this time?  Sometimes I think they want to keep doing a tx if it's working no matter what it does to your body.  It might be time to weigh QOL versus effectiveness.   If the neuropathy improves after you're off Abraxane for a while, you can always try it again later, since it does work for you. I did 6 tx of Taxol/Herceptin - my onc wanted to do at least 8.  I did them every 3 weeks instead of weekly.  I asked if going weekly would help lessen the cumulative neuropathy, and they told me it would still be about the same, so I stuck with the 3 week schedule.  My liver was stable on it, and my spine mets showed some healing, but the results weren't spetacular - who knows if it was the Taxol or Herceptin?  I wasn't going to allow myself to end up having a lot of problems with my hands.  As it is, I drop things a lot, and have problems picking up small items.  Each tx I was getting a little bit number.  I'm alone during the week, as my husband travels, so I'm not willing to end up with mobility problems, and not being able to take care of myself.  It's something you need to discuss with your dr.  Loss of mobility is a very serious side effect/issue, and should be avoided if possible.  Maybe it's time to switch to a different treatment. I've been doing a little research on the nueropathy issue.  Acetyl-L-Carnitine has shown some good results in actually healing and reversing the nerve damage that causes the neuropathy.  I'm going to talk to my onc and see about trying it when he puts me on one of the chemos that cause it.  Vitamin E has also been shown effective in decreasing the chance of getting neuropathy.  This can be such a debilitating side effect.  Personally, I'm not willing to become bed  or chair-bound in order to lengthen my life.  In my situation, I'd have to go into assisted living, and as an active 55 year old, I'm certainly not ready for a nursing home!  I'd have to give up way too much, including my furry friend in my avatar!  My husband is legally blind and can't drive, so getting around would be extremely difficult.  Our home is 2 stories with all the bedrooms/full baths on the 2nd floor, and garage/laundry in the basement.  So I couldn't live there. There are times when the treatment is worse then the disease itself.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 10:07AM - edited Sep 2, 2011 10:08AM by mthomp2020 No, you're not being a witch.  Being asked continually about how you're doing can get very old, very fast.  If you're actively involved in the community, and have kids in school, then there's a lot of people who may know your situation.  They're well-meaning, but don't realize that having to constantly answer the same questions can get pretty stressful, especially if you don't really want to talk about it.  There's a website - I  believe it's called Caring Bridge, maybe someone else will know more about it - where you can post any information you want regarding treatment and how you're doing.  It could save you from a lot of unwanted questions. Aren't the animals wonderful at a time like this?  The dogs are such great companions - no questions, just lots of cuddling and loving.  And escaping to the barn to be with your horses - it's like an entirely different world, where you forget everything else.  Riding, and even just a long grooming session, really takes you out of yourself, and the rest of the world just disappears.  I can't ride anymore due to a spinal tumor, and my mare has arthritis, so grooming is about it for me!  I do enjoy the time I spend with her, though.  She certainly doesn't miss the riding part! Just hang in there.  You're still pretty new to all this.  Eventually things will settle down, and it will get better.

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2009 04:29PM mthomp2020 wrote: My insurance only has 2 providers in the area.  One of them only carries one brand of prothesis/bras, Classique.  Lots of choice, huh?  Plus, they're hours are kind of odd and you have to set up an appointment.  The second shop carries more brands, so it is better.  My insurance only allows 2 bras per year - how generous!  I've been buying on-line, since I'm not particularly fond of the bras that were covered by insurance.  I even asked the shop about "upgrading", and they said you have to buy the bra and then file with the insurance company yourself for the reimbursement for the difference.  Way too much hastle, if you ask me. I even bought a new form on-line, and it worked out great.  Again, when I went to the fitter, I mentioned that I was interested in a climate control type form, as I do sweat a great deal.  She said "you can just put a cover on it, and the pocket in the bra will also make it OK.  The form I ended up with was comfortable, but I would sweat right through the pocket, even during cold weather.  No way I could wear it without a cover in a regular bra, either.  Gets kind of annoying to have your chest damp all the time!  I now have a Silique Comfort Lite, and I no longer sweat through the bra.  Plus, it doesn't pull that side of the bra down like my old form did.  I'm only a large A, so I hate to think how far down the proth side would hang if I were larger! The best fitters in my areas are not providers for my insurance, unfortunately, so I'm pretty much stuck with what I have.

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: Well, looks like Gemzar is actually doing something for me.  My scans this month showed no changes in any area, so I'm hanging with the Stable Boy.  I have lesions in my right hip, L-3 vertabrae, and a rib on the right side.  I've been lucky that I've responded to each chemo.  I got 1 1/2 years from Navelbine, so maybe I can do the same with Gemzar.  I've been on it since January, and it's been pretty easy on me.  No dose reductions due to low wbc or platelets.  It's made my feet and hands number, but that's really about it so far.  The L-3 has been problematic, since it's causing compression on the nerve root on my right side.  I'm pretty crippled up in the morning and late evening.  Advil actually is proving to be my best pain reliever.  3 in the morning, and I'm good during the day, and I take another 3 at night.  The narcotic pain relievers do squat, plus they plug me up.  Now if the damn weather would cool down a bit, I'd get out and do some walking, which I haven't been able to do since the beginning of the year.  To say the least, I'm a bit out of shape!  I have a pool and could swim, but there's no one here during the day besides me, and I won't swim alone, too risky.  Marsha Dx 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: Got my results today when I had my Herceptin tx. LIVER IS CLEAR _ NED!!!!  Just a 4mm fluid filled cyst, which is just a cyst.  Report said there were no definite lesions on the scan.  A year ago there were a lot of lesions, they didn't even say how many on the report, and some were large. Also, only bone met of 6 on my spine they mentioned was one that was lytic, and it's nearly healed as well, not a mention of the other ones, which were all sclerotic. Now I won't worry about every little twinge in my back for a while!  I sure wasn't expecting such great news.  My last scan after 4 Taxol/Herceptin tx showed my liver was stable, and the bones showed a little healing, so I was hoping for at least that.  It was the A/C before that that really worked on my liver.  I did another 2 Taxols/Herceptin after the previous scan, and just Herceptin for the last 2.  Apparently the Taxol just took a while to kick in. Since Taxol obviously worked for me, I guess I can go back and use it or another Taxane.  Just have to let some of the numbness clear up, which is why I stopped it in the first place.  For now, I get to cruise along on just the Herceptin.  Time to plan our trip to Vancouver Island and the Pacific Rim National Forest! Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: I just felt like venting - sorry it's so long. My husband is legally blind, and can't drive. He relies on me, friends and cabs for transportation. He's an IT consultant, and is out of town during the week, which works out well, as he then only needs transport to and from the airport. His company reimburses for cabs. He makes a very good living. Our house and car are paid off, and we don't have children, so we just have his retirement to worry about. He has an old friend from high school who had moved to New Jersey many years ago. He moved back to Cincinnati after hubby told him about my being stage IV. This guy is a drug user, and he's done time. That's one reason he moved to NJ. My husband pays him to drive him to and from the airport, as the company won't reimburse us for mileage but will for cab service. This guy needs the money, as he currently only works as a dishwasher for a small deli/restaurant. A lot of his income goes up his nose. He lives with a brother in a one room efficiency apt. He has another brother and a half sister that he lived with until they kicked him out. He tried to talk my hubby into moving into our house, but there's no way I'd want him here - I can't stand him, and he can't stand me. Even hubby couldn't take living with him. Now here's what I actually find really funny. We have a modest 4 bedroom home, with an inground pool and a hot tub. We also have satellite and HD TV. So not a hard place to live in. The other day, he told my husband he has a plan. When I die, he'd move in and take care of the house and our dog and cat during the week while hubby works. (Chances are the dog and cat would just be let out the door and end up dead because they were hit by a car, since that's what happened with his sister's dog). Plus someone would be there in the house so it wouldn't be empty. He'd "take care" of the pool and hot tub. And he would use the car, since it's just sitting there (his vehicle is on it's last leg), and drive him around on weekends when needed. He wouldn't be doing housework or yardwork. He's willing to do all this for just $2000 a month! When my hubby told me this, I just started laughing. He almost laughed in the guy's face too, and told him it wouldn't be hard to find someone who would gladly do this for nothing, in return for a a place to live and a car available. I always told hubby up front that this is why the guy moved back here, so he'd have a place to live, and he'd expect to be paid to live here. He's 57, and I think he considers my husband to be his retirement plan. If it weren't for the fact that the company won't reimburse us for mileage (it's 160 miles per week to and from the airport, plus up to 2 hours in the car each trip), I'd drive him myself and tell him to give this guy the boot. He is a complete loser. He was actually living in his van in NJ for several months before moving back here. He's got a lot of gall, I'll give him that! Rant over.  Quite the soap opera, isn't it?! Marsha Dx 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

I really don't know why my husband still wants to associate with this guy.  In reality, he could have a regular cab take him back and forth.  If the company balks at paying the extra cash, then we could just pay the difference.  I'm really afraid that something could happen and my husband would end up in trouble with the law.  If he went to jail, he'd lose everything he's worked for all these years.  He says he knows the guy is using him, and he has at times started to distance himself from him, but then his friend starts to insinuate himself back into his life again.  There's some other things as well that I can't really discuss on a public board that keep him hanging with this guy.  Let's just say if they pass a medical marijuana bill in Ohio, I'll be relieved.  Other friends who know about all this keep telling him he needs to stay away from him. Oh, and to top it all off, there's a woman who he knows from high school/college who recently asked him if she "had a chance" after I'm gone!  I'd told him a long time ago that the minute she heard about me being stage IV, she thought she might have a chance to marry him.  He really can't stand being around her, so it is pretty funny.  She's 4'11" and over 200 lbs, and she's really obnoxious (We've socialized with her and her ex-husband in the past, and I never did like her).  Before we married, she lectured me on taking good care of my husband.  This woman has been married 2 times, and the guy she's been living with won't marry her.  Mainly because he'd have to support her daughter and son-in-law and their 3 children.  Wow, Sincity - sounds like your brother!  I really don't know where my hubby finds these people!  He's got a couple of other friends that go back that far that are almost as bad.  He seems to be the only one of his group who made something of his life and isn't a loser.  I just wish he'd find some more normal friends.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2012 12:49PM - edited Feb 17, 2012 12:52PM by mthomp2020 I've considered a house cleaner, but the house cleaning wouldn't really help all that much.  Even if I had someone in once a week, you usually can't get someone the day you're having company  (every Saturday in our case), so I still have to clean when somone comes over, since we have a heavily shedding dog and cat.  Most the reasonable cleaners are only available during the week.  The ones available on weekends seem to charge $150 or more per cleaning.  If I was ambitious, I could clean the floors once a day!  I really only thorough clean once a week, and the house doesn't get all that dirty, so it doesn't take that long.  I always clean up after myself.  Most messes are from hubby cooking breakfast or fixing lunch - he's not too careful, and doesn't do a good job of cleaning up after himself.  He's legally blind, so he really can't see too well what he's doing.  He does do a good job at doing laundry, which is good since he seems to produce a lot of it! Part of my problem is we live in a 2-story home, with bedrooms and full baths on the second floor, and laundry and garage in the basement.  I do worry sometimes that I won't be able to handle stairs at some point and will have to go live in assisted living.  Hubby can't drive due to vision, so I'm the sole driver, so I can't send him out to do shopping for me if I'm not feeling up to it.  His cooking leaves a lot to be desired, so I don't depend on him to help in that area.  He can't/won't read directions when cooking, so if he tries to do something, I have to tell him how and show him, so it's just easier to do it myself.  I think the biggest problem is that since my activity is so limited, I'm pretty bored at times.  I do needlework/beading/jewelry making, but you can only do so much of that before you get burnt out on it.  I really don't like to sit around and watch TV all day, and I can't seem to get interested in picking up a book and reading.  I'm hoping when the weather warms up in the spring I can at least get out and sit in the sun, maybe take the dog to a dog park.  When summer comes, we have a swimming pool and I plan on getting out in it almost every day and getting some exercise, which I think is part of the problem.  It's really hard going from being active to so in-active.  Compounding things, I have lymphadema in my right leg from hip radiation, so I have to be careful of that, and it does cause some of the hip pain at times.  A palliative/pain care doctor would be a good idea.  Just have to figure out how to locate one in my area.  My onc keeps wanting to throw narcotics at it, but they just don't work on the type of pain I have.  Percocet didn't even put a dent in it, and made me throw up.

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 06:55PM mthomp2020 wrote: One thing that bothers me to some degree is the talk of prevention.  Let's face it, the only real prevention seems to be for BRAC1, and even then there's still a 10% chance of recurrence even after getting a bi-lat mastectomy before you've actually had BC.  With all the different types of BC out there, there's really no good way to determine what might prevent it.  I'm a believer that it's largely environmental, so outside of moving to some corner of the world where BC is uncommon, there's no real way to prevent it.  Let's face it, it is pretty much a crap shoot who ends up with BC. I'd rather see the money go to the new findings in BC stem cell research and genetic causes.  That's where there will probably be real break-throughs, and some hope of a true cure.

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: A question for those of you who are currently on Herceptin or were in the past.  How long did your onc have you on Herceptin?  I'm coming up on a year in October, and it sounds as if they'll stop it at one year, even though I'm Stage IV.  My next appt. is 10/6, and I guess I'll know for sure then.  So far I haven't had progression, I've actually been in remission, and not doing chemo at this time, just the Herceptin and Zometa.  On one hand, it may make sense to stop it for a while to avoid developing resistance to it.  On the other hand, I certainly would feel a lot safer if I stayed on it.  I had one MUGA that dropped from 64 to 54 in 3 months, but the follow-up scan 6 weeks later was back up to 62, so no problem in that area. Did your onc stop it after a year, but used it again with chemo when you had progression?  Enquiring minds want to know! Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2008 05:42PM mthomp2020 wrote: The only problem with the power port is that they can't use them for the bone scans, which I get at the same time as my CT, as they can't use them for tests using radioactive isatopes (i.e. bone and MUGA scans).  So I still have to get stuck, unfortunately.  But at least when they stick you for the MUGA scans (twice), they use a regular small bore needle instead of a catheter.  If I ever have to get my port replaced, I'll ask for a power port instead.  Now when I get my CT scans, the hospital wants to do bloodwork first to check creatine and BUN - apparently some people can end up with kidney failure because of the contrast dye - so they end up sticking me to take blood, and they use a large-bore needle to do it.  Can't win for losing!

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 04:00PM mthomp2020 wrote: Too many hobbies, too little time! My number one hobby - actually, more of a passion - is horseback riding. I've been a horseowner for over 30 years. I've been very fortunate that I've been able to ride with no problem throughout my chemo treatments. I have spinal mets, but they've healed and were never advanced enough to keep me off my horse. Next to that, all kinds of needlework. I learned to knit when I was 12, and taught myself how to crochet. Great projects to bring along to chemo. I also do cross-stitch and needlepoint. My most recent thing has been beadweaving using seed beads. I've been making beaded Christmas ornament covers for the past 3 years and giving them as gifts. I usually do all my bead/needlework while watching TV - keeps me from falling asleep! I acquired a kitten this summer, so it has been a bit of a challenge! I can actually do my knitting/crocheting with him around, but for some reason when I'm beading, he loves to grab at the thread when it moves, so I have to ban him to the basement while I work on a project. I used to read quite a bit, but now seem to only do it on vacation, though I can usually finish 3 books while I'm away. When I'm at home, I tend to do my beadwork or needlework instead. I just really enjoy doing anything with my hands. I used to do a lot of sketching, mostly horses and animals, but I've gotten away from that over the years. Maybe I'll take it up again when I have more time - like that'll ever happen! I've always wanted to try my hand at painting with watercolors, so maybe I'll sign up for a class some time in the future. I agree, great topic!

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 10:47AM mthomp2020 wrote: I've had a liver biopsy, and it wasn't that bad.  Less painful then my breast biopsy, actually.  Mine was a CT guided fine needle aspiration.  It was done with a local and no sedation.  Biggest problem was they had trouble getting enough viable cells, as the chemo had already killed off some of the lesion they took the sample from, so they had to take about 4 samples instead of one.  That, and I had to hold my breath while they were taking the sample - kind of hard with your liver jiggling around under your diaphragm!   It didn't hurt that the doc was definitely in the McDreamy category, though!  No pain or soreness afterwards, either.  Good luck - I'll keep my fingers crossed it comes up HER2+.  I wish I would come up ER/PR+ so I had some more non-chemo options myself.

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 05:39AM - edited Jan 26, 2011 05:42AM by mthomp2020 Wow, Lowrider - I definitely feel for you!  Sounds like you've been put through the wringer.  I hope the surgery can relieve your pain.  For the narrowing of the neural foramen, apparently there's a laser procedure that can be done on an out-patient basis, I believe with a laparascope.  Spine surgery has come quite a ways.  I'll bet just getting rid of that pain will have you skipping and jumping!  Of course, don't do that until the doctor says it's OK!   Fortunately, I don't have any other issues with my back, outside of normal wear and tear.  I did have a sclerotic lesion at T-6, but it's healed/inactive.  There's some bone spurring, and I can sometimes feel a twinge if I move a certain way, but otherwise it's never given me any problems.  Apparently, the L-3 is completely involved, including the pedicles, and extends into the soft tissue around the bone and nerve root.  It's lytic rather then sclerotic, so there's a lot of bone loss.  Who knows, maybe I will get some relief from the radiation - keeping my fingers crossed on that!  I could look into the accupuncture.  Unfortunately, it would be entirely out of pocket, as insurance only covers it as anesthesia for surgery.  How much does a single accupuncture tx cost?  Let us know if it helps with the nerve pain.  The pain isn't continual - mainly seems to be in the morning after I get up, and seems to subside throughout the day, but returns in the evening - probably because I do more sitting/watching TV then.  If I'm on my feet a lot, it'll aggravate it too.  It doesn't bother me at night when I go to bed, but you can't lay in bed all day long.  If it didn't worsen, I guess I could live with it, but I don't think I could take it 24/7.  If you're dealing with it continually, you're one strong woman! I gather that you're on Zometa.  Have you found it helps with bone pain?  So far, I haven't had any bone pain from the mets, just the nerve pain and some muscle pain from my right hip, which is nicely covered with lesions extending into the muscle.  So I've got to be careful not to strain the muscle - ask me how I know that!  If it wasn't for the nerve compression, I wouldn't know there was that bad an issue.

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2009 04:14PM mthomp2020 wrote: If it wasn't for the neuropathy, I could do Taxol again.  I only did 6 tx's, and it put me into remission for a year.  So it would still work.  Unfortunately, that's what started the neuropathy in the first place.  I was actually supposed to do 8 tx's, but I stopped at 6 because of the way the numbness was increasing with each tx.  In a year the numbness never improved, it just stayed pretty much the same.  Now it's getting worse after only 3 tx's.  I'm having to be careful about walking so I don't trip.  Plus I'm dropping things a lot.  I really have no idea what my onc is going to "suggest" as my next tx.  Actually, he doesn't suggest, he just tells me "we're doing x treatmen starting today". There is no discussion or options given.  Guess I'll find out on Monday, I can hardly wait!  I can still do Gemzar, and there's still Xeloda and Tykerb.  Plus the Super Herceptin.  Since I've already lost about half my hair - I now need to wear a hat or scarf - I'm hoping for Gemzar.  That way I can get the hair loss over and done with!  I just wish they could find some way to prevent the nerve damage so many of these chemos cause.  I can deal with the hair loss, but not the nerve loss.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 01:29PM - edited Feb 18, 2012 01:33PM by mthomp2020 I appreciate all the input from you ladies.  Gives me a lot to consider.  I have been using Ativan a bit to help me sleep - 1/2 a miligram at night.  I've also taken one when I'm feeling really anxious/nervous, and it does a lot to bring me down, and I do feel a lot better.  Mornings are really the worst part of the day for me.  I usually just get up and take my pain meds and drink my coffee and read the paper, then veg on the couch listening to some morning shows while the meds kick in.  Then I feel like I can get moving and accomplish a few things. Bestbird, I've had many hobbies over the years.  Most types of needlework, beading and beadweaving, piano, drawing - numb fingers make some of it difficult to do.  I currently do a great deal of knitting, and when I'm working on a project, it definitely helps.  You can only do so much of that in a day, though.  Whenever a new craft catches my interest, I teach myself how to do it.  Just running out of new things that interest me!  It probably would help to talk to someone, but it seems as if everyone wants to tell me about their issues and problems rather then listen to me.  When they're depressed, they call ME - maybe it makes them feel better when they compare their problems to mine!  I guess that's where a pro could help - you pay them to listen! I do try to find a good movie to watch, but comedies are my favorite, and there just doesn't seem to be that many good ones out there anymore.  We have satellite, so there's a good number to choose from, but sometimes I just can't find anything I want to watch.  A good comedy really makes me feel better and puts me in a good mood.  Whenever I see something that looks interesting, I record it for later.  That way, if it's not very good, I haven't wasted money on a rental and I can just delete it. I actually haven't been bursting into tears.  Just feel like I want to scream sometimes.  I made it through 4 years of this without feeling the need for an anti-depressant.  It really wasn't until I had to start dealing with the leg lymphedema on top of the hip pain that I started feeling like this.  We all have our breaking point, I guess. Hubby has been talking about maybe being able to work from home at times instead of going to the client site.  It would help just having someone here - it does get lonely here while he's out of town.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 01:06AM mthomp2020 wrote: To be honest, I don't worry about my port showing.  I don't notice it, and I do wear some tops that don't cover it - I never give that a thought.  I did Navelbine for a 1 1/2 years, and I certainly wouldn't have attemped it without my port.  I started on a schedule of 10 weeks on, 2 off, and did this for 2 cycles, then switched to every other week.  Most people do it 3 on, 1 off.  I was stage IV at the get-go.  The first rounds of chemo wiped out my liver mets, and healed my bone mets.  I had a year off of chemo, with just Herceptin and Zometa, before a new area showed up in my hip.  Even if you do get a chemo break, you still might be on Herceptin for a while.  When I did my first round of chemo (6 A/C, 6 Taxol/Herceptin), they told me upfront that I needed a port.  I've never had any issue with it.  My only reason for not wearing lower cut tops is my mastectomy - the port is a non-issue for me.  Once you have a port, you'll wonder why you waited so long!  A port really will make your treatment soooo much easier.  I've seen so many people in the tx center who didn't have one go through multiple sticks for one tx - not fun.

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: I thought I'd post about a great cami that I found not too long ago. Pre-mastectomy, I wore camis and tanks with shelf bras more then I wore regular bras, just because they were so much more comfortable. After my single mastectomy, most of the camis were too low and would tend to gap on that side. If I were a bi-lat, it probably would be OK, but with one side it's an issue. So I'm always trying to find something that can work for me. I found a great cami at TJ Maxx. It's by Nouvelle Seamless Intimates. It's actually a pretty snug fitting cami, as it's supposed to be shapeware. It does give mild compression all over, so it smooths you out a bit, but I don't find it too tight at all. I pin one of my Amoena 126's into it. Just too lazy to try to sew a pocket in it! I only paid $10 for it. I'm a size 12, and usually wear a large in tops. I bought it in an XL, and it fits very well without being too tight. It's high enough that the concavity on my mast side isn't noticable, and it doesn't gap out when you bend over. I'd have to say this was a great find! Unfortuately, last time I went to TJ, they didn't have any in my size. However, I did some searching on-line and found someone on eBay that carries them, so I ordered a couple more of them. I saw them in white, black, gray, nude, and I think coral. The price wasn't as good, I think about $16-17, but still not that bad. I highly recommend these. They're great under a blouse or a lower cut knit shirt for a layered look.  If you have a TJ Maxx near you, check to see if they have any.  At that price, you can't lose! Even though I don't have lymphadema, I sometimes do get a little sore and puffy under my arm if I wear a bra all day. Even some of the other camis cause this because of the elastic band. For some reason, this cami doesn't bother me much at all, probably because there's more of an all-over compression. So it would probably be perfect for someone with truncal lymphadema. Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: I'm at the point now where I need to start taking something. I wake up each morning thinking "I hate my life", and dread getting up. Due to nerve pain in my right hip/leg, I do very little, as walking and standing is painful. I'm alone most the time except on weekends, as my husband travels as a consultant. I can't get out and walk my dog, or go shopping for fun - it's not fun if it hurts. So my big outings are grocery shopping once a week, and going out to dinner with friends on the weekend. Even when we go out, we always end up back at our house. I'm getting pretty tired of looking at these 4 walls all the time. Plus my blood pressure has been elevated, and my PCP doubled the dose, which was the smallest dose you can be on. It doesn't seemt to be doing the job. I'm afraid maybe the Herceptin might be affecting my heart now after almost 5 years on it. What anti-depressants seem to work well for you ladies? I certainly don't want to be a zombie, but I'd like to wake up in the morning without dreading getting through another day. I was doing really well until my back and hip problems started a year ago, and even then managed OK until this fall/winter. My scans in January were stable, so that's not the cause of feeling this way. Now I really need to do something to pull myself out of this funk and bring a little joy back into my life. Maybe just getting on something will help with my blood pressure, as stress is a big cause of raised blood pressure for me. I've been using a little Ativan, and it helps, but I need more help then that. I try to get out with friends or family once during the week, but they're busy with work and their own families, so it isn't that often - maybe once or twice a month. When I'm having a good time with people and hubby is with me, he sometimes cuts things short and shoos people out of the house or whisks me away early, even though I tell him I'm OK and having fun. A friend has noticed this as well. I think he worries about me overdoing it, as I have to clean the house (with his help) prior to getting together, since as I said before, we always end up back at our place.  Nobody else seems to want to entertain at their house anymore, so hubby always has them over here every weekend. Thanks for listening. I'd been hoping to avoid anti-depressants for a while longer, but it's time now to start on one. Hopefully se's aren't bad. I already feel I'm taking WAY too many pills a day as it is! If it makes me feel better and sleep better, it'll be worth it, though. 　 Marsha Dx 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2011 05:09PM - edited Jun 27, 2011 05:21PM by mthomp2020 Reesie already beat me to it.  Lytic lesions do eat bone.  Until last August, I had sclerotic lesions in my right hip and one rib.  They never bothered me.  I was able to ride my horse pain free.  I actually did some dirt-surfing and cracked 4 ribs as it turned out, none of which had cancer in them.  Didn't damage any affected areas at all.  If you saw my hip on the bone scan, you'd probably thinkg "that's got to hurt!".  Last August scans showed a lytic lesion in my L-3 vertabrae, and by December I was having a great deal of pain.  However, that was being caused by root nerve compression, and the tumors growing into the muscle/soft tissue.  To this day, I really don't have bone pain, except that when I sneeze the affected rib hurts. My thinking is that the lytic lesions tend to be more painful, since bone is being destroyed at a faster rate then your body can counter-act.  Sclerotic lesions keep laying more bone down on the affected area, surrounding the cancerous bone tissue with more bone to control it.  I would think if it's happening in a joint, it could cause pain the same way arthritis does.  I hear you about not being able to do the things you love to do.  Right now I can't even take my dog for a walk, let alone ride my horse.  Hard to give up the riding after 30+ years.  But you just try to adjust to the new normal.  If the weather would warm up a bit, I could jump in my pool and enjoy that.  You do what you can do.  On the plus side, my knitting and jewelry making have been highly productive!  Looks like people will be getting lots of hand-made gifts this year!

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2010 11:21AM - edited Jan 19, 2010 11:22AM by mthomp2020 I'm sorry to hear that you're having so much trouble with the neuropathy.  In my case, Neurontin did help with the pain.  I had leg pain, but I never did have pain or tingling in my feet or hands, I went straight to numbness, which none of these medications helped in the slightest.  I'm currently on Navelbine, which did aggravate the neuropathy and cause more numbness.  One thing I'm doing for it is to take 30 grams a day of L-Glutamine, and it does seem to help slow down the numbness progression.  PM me if you need more info.  I understand it can also help with the pain.  I've been on Navelbine since March, and it seems to be keeping the neuropathy at bay. Another thing you could look into is Acetyl-L-Carnitine.  One of the big cancer centers, it might be M.D.Anderson, is currently doing a trial with it to see if can prevent/lessen neuropathy.  Do a search on it and see what comes up.  You could talk to your onc about trying this to see if it gives you any relief.  Plus, if you do end up going on Taxotere, it might help the neuropathy from getting worse.  Taxotere can definitely cause it, as it's one of the taxanes.  My onc is all gung-ho about Abraxane these days, and mentioned it as a possible chemo.  It's a formulation of Taxol, which caused my neuropathy.  When I said something about that, he replied "the side effects go away in 4-6 weeks after you stop it".  That may be true of the pain, but nerves do not grow back.  He seems to ingore the numbness issue, and only focuses on the pain aspect.

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: Kind of bummed today. I'm HR/PR-, HER2 +, Stage IV with mets to liver and "suspicious" spots on spine. I had excellent results with 6 A/C treatments, liver mets either shrank or disappeared, areas on spine didn't change one way or the other, so I was hoping they were just old injury/possible arthritis. I just had my 5th Taxol/Herceptin tx today. I had CT scans before Christmas. I was told the results of the scans today, saw the NP rather then the onc, and he said he had good news/bad news. Liver was stable, no progression or decrease after 4 treatments. The spots on the spine did, however, shrink some. So, obviously they were mets. It's interesting that the A/C had no affect on them, but the Taxol/Herceptin did. Sounds like the Taxol/Herceptin isn't kicking butt on the liver like I'd hoped, but at least there's no progression. To top it all off, right before Christmas I found a lump in my remaining breast. It was clean back in May, with both mammo and MRI. So now I've got an appointment with my surgeon next Monday to have that checked out. So Happy New year! It would just be my luck to end up with another bc during chemo! I was really hoping that the current treatment would help get rid of some more of the smaller mets. The spots on the spine seem to be pretty small, so I would love to see those go away completely. But 4 treatments shrunk them just a little. My onc wanted to do 3 more Taxol tx's, but my finger numbness gets a little worse each time, and I might not be able to continue with it. At least I'm not having any kind of pain from my back, so if it stays stable that's something. Just a shame the A/C is so limited in how many times you can do it, as my results were great with it. I even had a 7 week break for surgery during A/C, and still ended up with more shrinkage with the last 2 treatments. I don't know why, but I had a feeling that the Taxol just wasn't going to be nearly as effective as the A/C for that. I'm only 7 months into this rollercoaster ride. Guess I'd better buckle my seatbelt, it's gonna be a bumpy ride! Marsha Dx 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2010 10:41AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:22AM by mthomp2020 Hey, I really can't complain.  I've had these hip mets for over a year and a half without them causing any problems.  It's not so much that the pain is so bad the vicodan doesn't touch them - it's just that vicodan has never done anything for me.  I've had it a couple of times, and it didn't do a thing.  Last time I tried it was when I had my port installed.  It was like I took nothing at all.  Advil actually works much better for me, and I get a good 6 hours of relief out of 3 or 4 advil.  When my hip acted up before, it totally took care of the pain. Fortunately, the pain isn't constant, but getting up out of a chair is a real challenge.  One can't stand on their feet all day.  Once I'm verticle and moving it gets better.  The percocet takes the edge off, and it definitely gave me a good night's sleep last night.  I'll ask about adding naproxen to the percocet, since that can really help with the inflamation.  The NSAIDs really seem to work much better for me. I think the area on my hip that's giving me trouble is where the muscle/ligament attach, so when I'm getting up or bending over, it pulls on it.  Fortunately, my mets in my hip are sclerotic, so the bone isn't being eaten away.  I'm sure the rads will help. Fitz, has adding the Tykerb helped your bone mets?  I'd like something to at least stop them.  I have a lytic lesion on L-3 that showed up on my August scans, and has gotten worse, and that's the one that's really of concern to me.  I haven't particularly noticed any issues with it yet, but that could change any time.  I'd like to stop that one in it's tracks before I've lost too much bone.  Maybe adding Carbo like Kona would do the job.  The Navelbine never really gave me any improvement, it kept things pretty stable though. The worse things about the rads will be having to go every day.  I have to drive myself, so I might not be able to take the pain med before going.  I'm not particularly anxious about it, I just want to get on with it and get it done.  Hey, at least I'll still have my hair for the holidays!

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2008 02:39PM mthomp2020 wrote: The TLC website has mastectomy bras that are pretty inexpensive - usually in the $25-$30 range.  Playtex makes a mastectomy bra that's only about $20 - try an on-line search.  Metromedical online has Amoena closeouts for a good price, too.  One thing you might try is to find a regular bra that could work with a prosthesis.  I just bought a Hanes bra at Target for $9 that fits really well, and my form fits in it perfectly.  If you don't mind doing a little bit of sewing, you can buy 4 pockets from TLC for about $13 and sew them into the bra, or just try putting your form in the bra cup and see if it stays put. Sometimes you can find a good deal on a Classique bra online - do a search on Classique and see if anything comes up. I don't think there's any such thing as an inexpensive mastectomy bra!

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2010 10:26AM mthomp2020 wrote: Here's my rant. The other morning I had the news on, and then the program with Hoda and Kathy Lee. They had Dr. Susan Love and another doctor on talking about BC. They both were all about how important it was to concentrate on prevention, no mention of cure. There are so many causes of bc, how in hell can you possibly prevent it? The only type you have a chance of preventing is BRCA1, and you have to take pretty drastic measures to do it, and even then there's still a very small chance you can still get bc, since you can't every little bit of breast tissue in a mastectomy. They said diet and exercise can help, but it's certainly no gaurantee, as women who have done everything right and lived very healthy lifestyles still develop bc, and some of them die from it. Personally, I think the "cause" of bc is largely environmental, and it's very difficult if not impossible to control that aspect. Unless you grow and raise your own food so you know exactly what goes into it, you can't control that aspect of it. The very air we breath contains carcinogens. So it's pretty much a crap-shoot who does and doesn't get bc. It really all boils down to the fact that the only real prevention of bc deaths is a cure. Something that can turn off the "switch" that triggers the cells to grow, which is currently being researched for several different cancers. I wish the money they're trying to raise for "prevention" for bc would instead go into finding cures for each type of bc, which would save a lot more lives then prevention. Plus it could keep women from having to go through the surgery, chemo and radiation they now have to endure in order to be "cured". Which of course, isn't really a true cure, as many of the women here can attest to. I periodically get calls from an organization that wants me to mail and give out material to women in my area about using diet, exercise and a healthy lifestyle as prevention for bc, and I don't waste my time talking to them, as I don't truly believe it's a preventative. I'd sooner use my time/money on a cure.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2011 03:43PM - edited Nov 19, 2011 03:44PM by mthomp2020 My experience has been that lytic lesions don't always show up well on bone scans unless they're large.  They do show up on CAT scans, though.  MRI's give a very clear picture, but they usually only use them when you're experiencing a large amount of pain, and they want a clear picture of the amount of damage there is. I do have soft tissue involvement with my bone mets, which is what's causing pain.  The CT scan shows tumor growing into the soft tissue from the illiac crest.  There's also soft tissue involvement by my L-3 vertabrae as well.  The bone mets themselves don't hurt, though if you saw my bone scan, you'd wonder why they don't.  My right hip is riddled with sclerotic lesions, and my L-3 is badly damaged with a lytic lesion.  Zometa must be doing it's job!

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2011 10:13AM - edited Dec 16, 2011 10:14AM by mthomp2020 I was Stage IV from the get-go.  After completing my initial chemo (6 AC, 6 Taxol/Herceptin), I was NED.  I was off chemo after that, doing Herceptin/Zometa only, for a year before I had progression in my hip.  I enjoyed every minute of being chemo-free, and I wasn't worried about being off chemo, since I continued with Herceptin. I think it helps to give your body a break from chemo if at all possible.  Have you talked to your onc about taking a break?  You can always restart the chemo if anything pops up again.  The Herceptin can keep things at bay just by itself.  Maybe you could get a 2nd opinion.  Some oncs think you need to be on continuous chemo, some don't.  My onc prefers not to go through chemos too fast if he can help it.  In reality, the only way you know if you need to stay on chemo is to stop it for a while.

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 03:31AM mthomp2020 wrote: Dreamwriter, you hit the nail on the head.  My first visit with him when this started didn't last more then 10 minutes.  My husband was with me, and he discussed sports part of the time, rather then my case (Hubby tends to monopolize the conversation, so he no longer goes with me to any dr. visits).  The visit when he told me I was stage IV was 5 minutes, tops.  I had a friend with me for that visit, and she didn't have much of an opnion of him on how he handled it. Hope4us, arrogant is exactly who another poster here described him after she and her husband consulted with him.  Needless to say, she didn't go to him.  There never has been any discussions, just him telling me what's what.  If I didn't pick up my scan results and read them before my appointments, he probably wouldn't tell me what's really going on.  When I was initially diagnosed I was already stage IV.  When he told me the results of the scans, he said I had multiple liver lesions and "a" spot on my spine.  Shortly after that, I went and got copies of my scans.  Turns out I had 5-6 different areas on my spine, and one on each hip, as well as too many liver lesions to count.  He has never discussed chemo "options" - just what chemo we're doing next.  One patient told him she was getting tired and worn out from all the chemo and wanted to stop, and his answer was, "I've kept you alive this long, haven't I?"  Sometimes I think it's a big contest to see just how long he can keep people going.  He has quite the ego.  By the way, his wife had breast cancer right around the time I first started this - you'd think he'd have a little more insight. Another woman who sees him had a big wedding for her daughter planned this summer.  She had some progression, and needed to change chemos - she's triple negative.  He wanted to put her on Ixempra, and she didn't want to do that right before the wedding.  She had people coming to stay with her, and wanted to be able to enjoy it.  She ended up going to someone else and got a 2nd opinion.  She ended up on Gemzar, and it did keep her stable and she got to enjoy her daughter's wedding.  She's now on Ixempra, and it's really kicking her butt.  I'm sure she's glad she stuck to her guns, since it would have been tough for her to handle the wedding.
