Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: Sorry if this is a little long, but I just need to talk/vent, and you guys are great listeners, and understand. After the spine MRI I had a week ago Monday showed that my entire L-3 vertebrae is cancerous, yesterday my onc finally admitted that Navelbine isn't working anymore. My scans in November said as much, but he didn't want to do anything at that time for some reason - said he didn't want to run through chemos too fast. The MRI must of looked pretty scarey to the radiologist who read it, since she tried to reach my onc 15 minutes after I was done with the MRI. The office was closed for MLK day, and she spoke to the doctor who was on call. However, it doesn't look like my onc received any information about the call, and I don't even think he saw the results of the MRI. I saw the NP instead of him - 2nd time in a row I've seen him for scan results rather then my onc. He asked if anyone had contacted me about it, and no one did. Anywho, I'm seeing a rads onc on Thursday, and then probably 2 weeks worth of rads to my spine. Problem is, I'm not going to get any pain relief, as I don't have any bone pain (thank you, Zometa!). The big issue right now is the left nerve root that passes through the vertabrae is being compressed because the opening has narrowed because of the cancer - MRI said moderate to severe stensosis. I get nerve pain running down from my hip to my knee, and some muscle cramping. The radiation isn't going to do anything to relieve that. As a matter of fact, I suspect it might further irritate the nerve and cause the pain to worsen. The only thing that would help it is is surgery. The radiation is for damage control, as I already have 25% compression in the end plate, so probably some chance of a compression fracture - probably why the radiologist called my office so quickly. Hopefully the rad onc will have some answers for me. I really feel that my onc dropped the ball on this. When I question him, he just brushes it off. One time he told me he was the captain of the ship! Guess what - I own the boat, he works for me! He doesn't seem to like patients who ask questions or have an opinion. He just wants us to be good little sheeple who go along with whatever he says. Some of his patients love him, but not this one. I think it's time to go shopping for a new one. If we had jumped on this back in November, I wouldn't be having as much trouble with the nerve, and possibly the vertabrae wouldn't be as bad. Too late now, though. When the L-3 showed up on my August scans, I was definitely concerned, but he didn't seem to be. Guess I need to listen to my gut from now on. Looks like I'll be starting Gemzar, too.  He wanted to start me on it in 2 weeks, which would be right in the middle of the radiation.  I'd have one day when I would be doing both chemo and radiation.  Is that usual?  I thought they never did both at the same time.  Something else I'll have to ask the rad onc on Thursday, I guess.  Thanks for listening, guys.  Marsha Dx 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: My entire right leg has been swelling, especially the foot/ankle area, for maybe a couple of months now. Initially it wasn't very much, and only seemed to be the foot/ankle, and it would go down with elevating the leg. In late July it started to swell more, and August 3rd my onc ordered a dopplar to see if it was a blood clot. It wasn't, and they said just keep an eye on it. I flew out to Seattle and back a few days after the dopplar - 4 hours each way - and maybe a week later the swelling got worse. The skin has been red and tender in different areas as well as the leg being swollen, and at one point it got pretty hot. Last week I started a week of Keflex in case it was cellulitis. The heat is gone, but still swollen and sore. Back in January, I had 15 radiation tx's to my spine and upper wing of my right hip. Then in April I had 5 rad tx's to the area not radiated before on my hip. I started to put 2 and 2 together this weekend, and began thinking lymphadema. I put a call in to my onc office this morning (no tx this week), and sure enough, the nurse who looked over my chart was thinking the same thing, so they're referring me to a lymphadema clinic. On one hand, it's great not to have a blood clot, but lymphadema will be a major pain to deal with. I know wrapping is an important part of the treatment, and I can't reach my right foot due to the tumor on my spine, so I have no idea how I'm going to be able to handle that. My hubby is only home on the weekend, plus he's legally blind, so no help. He couldn't even put a compression sock on my foot properly. Fortunately, from what I've read, it's in the early stages, and with the therapy the swelling can be reversed. Unfortunately, it means compression garments from now on. As if there's not enough to deal with being stage IV!  Well, at least summer is pretty much over so heat won't be a big issue until next summer. I just want to get the swelling down so I can wear shoes again. Right now I have real trouble tying my shoe laces on my right foot because I can't bend down that far. Marsha Dx 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2011 09:40AM - edited Sep 13, 2011 09:42AM by mthomp2020 Peggy, I'm surprised they didn't tell your mom right then whether or not she has a blood clot.  I didn't have to wait for that, they usually tell you right there.  Were you there with her when they performed the dopplar?  You said that your mom broke her hip.  Sometimes people get lymphadema in their leg after they break it, so it could well be what's going on.  If she has cancer in that hip and had radiation there, that could cause it too.  I had radiation on my right hip, and I think that's what's causing this problem.  Sad thing is, the radiation didn't do a thing for my hip pain, which is probably being caused by nerve root compression in my spine.  I hope they get everything straightened out and you find out what's going on.

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 04:49PM mthomp2020 wrote: I have neuropathy in the form of numbness from Taxol and Navelbine.  Lyrica and other drugs prescribed for neuropathy help with the pain, but not with the numbness issue.  One thing that might help is 30 grams/day of L-Glutamine powder mixed with some kind of cold beverage - juice or milk work well for mixing.  You might try going back on the lower dose, since you didn't have an issue on that dosage.  If you let the numbness get too bad, walking could get very difficult, and you can end up with drop foot, where your arch collapses.  Have you discussed any of this with your onc? I know with me the numbness never went away after getting Taxol.  A year later I started on Navelbine, and it made the numbness a bit worse.  The L-Glutamine I think has slowed it down, though.

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2007 08:24PM mthomp2020 wrote: Thanks for the encouraging words.  Just that having this around the holidays just makes a stressful time of the year moreso. I am hoping the lump is benign.  Sometimes it's pretty hard to find - I could feel it in the shower this morning, but couldn't find the darn thing at the doc's office!  Though I usually can feel it lying down, but not in the shower, so go figure!  One thing I did notice, I found it right after my flu shot (first one I've ever had) which I got the day after my last treatment, along with my Nuelasta.  The next day I was somewhat sore under that arm, and my lymph nodes seemed to be a bit swollen and hard.  They've been that way on again, off again since the shot.  So it could be something to do with that.  Guess it could be a really irritated lymph gland in the breast. Since I'm getting Taxol and Herceptin together, you can't really say which one is doing the most good.  If I have to drop the Taxol, I guess they might try just Herceptin and see what happens.  Herceptin can keep things stable, it just doesn't always shrink the tumors.  I know they can still use Tykerb, and Xeloda.  That combo seems to really help a lot of women.  I'm wondering if the receptors are different on my bone mets.  At this point, they aren't talking about doing a biopsy, and that's the only way to tell.  Guess I'll just have to wait and see how it goes.  There's a trial/study going on in Canada for testing if a chemo is actually working after one treatment.  They inject a radioactive dye that will attach itself to dying cancer cells, and then they do scans which show if there's any activity.  If there isn't, the chemo isn't working on the cancer.  If this becomes available soon, it'll save us so much hit and miss treatments and se's, and take the guess work out of treatment.  It will certainly save the insurance companies money!

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 11:16PM mthomp2020 wrote: The center I go to has 2 floors with one chemo room per floor.  The room's long and narrow, with chairs all along the wall.  I think they can do at least 20 people at a time, maybe more.  There's an area at one end that isn't being used right now and they have a curtain divider across it.  There isn't any privacy at all.  There's a folding tray table between each chair.  If you need to get up to use the bathroom, you have to maneuver the pole around everything.  There's a TV at one end. There do seem to be a number of lifers there.  Not everyone is all that old.  The other floor seems to have more elderly patients.  We also get people there for blood and iron transfusions, as they also do hematology as well.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 03:42PM mthomp2020 wrote: I fractured/cracked 4 ribs a year before last Thankgiving, and had a scheduled bone scan a week later.  The fractures didn't show up on Xray, but did on the bone scan.  If I hadn't injured them, they probably would have assumed new mets, as they really didn't look any different then the active mets we knew about.  What the bone scan shows is bone remodeling.  In my case, the osteoblastic/sclerotic lesions show up if they're active, but the lytic lesions aren't as obvious.  If you also do a CT scan along with the bone scan, they can compare the 2 and tell better if it's a fracture or a met, as they can see a bone callous on the CT scan.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2011 10:51AM mthomp2020 wrote: I did over a 1 1/2 years of Navelbine/Herceptin with no Decadron, just Zofran for premeds, and had no problem.  However, when they switched to a new computerized, paperless system, the computer automatically added decadron.  When they told me they were about to hook it up, I told them, nope, don't want it, don't need it, no way - after all, I'd been doing this a year without it, so why start now?  They went to my onc, who said something like "it'll help her".  With what?  This happened twice, and I refused it twice, so they finally got the message.  I'm getting it now with Gemzar, but I'm seriously considering asking them to drop it.  I always get a mild headache after my tx, which I never had when I didn't get Decadron, so I'm thinking that's the culprit.  Plus I don't appreciate not being able to sleep because of it.  I've been getting some ankle swelling at night, and wonder if dec is the culprit.  It didn't happen until I started the new tx. They've also tried a couple of times to give me Benadryl and Tylenol with Herceptin, and I always turn that down as well, as I've never had any kind of reaction to it.  Plus I usually take Claritin and Advil in the morning before tx, so that would be a bit of overkill.  If you saw what they charge for each of these drugs, you can see why they automatically give them - extra profit!
Posts.Title: Follow up to Decadron Discussions KSkier Jane1967

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2010 11:49AM mthomp2020 wrote: Well, I have sclerotic mets in my right hip in the socket and surrounding area that showed up  over 1 1/2 years ago, and I've been on Navelbine since, along with Herceptin and Zometa for over 2 years.  I never really had any pain unless I did something to aggravate it, and it went away with Advil.  I never really started having pain in the hip until this summer, so I thought it was progression.  When I had my scans at the beginning of August, the bone scan showed considerably less activity in my hip.  Which leads me to believe the pain was the hip starting to heal.  The times my hip hurt prior to the improvement could be pretty intense, my leg would almost give out until I'd moved around a little.  Now the pain is just generally some achieness, more like mild arthritis, and improves when I get some exercise.  I currently get bone and CT scans.  I've never had a PET scan.  The CT scan is more likely to show if there's healing going on.  I've had healing mentioned on my CT scans in the past when I had some spine mets.  They can go back and compare the previous CT's to the most recent and see what differences show up. I'll keep my fingers crossed that your scans show improvement.

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 11:15PM - edited Apr 30, 2009 11:16PM by mthomp2020 I'm using L-glutamine in powder form, 15 grams twice a day dissolved in juice or milk.  I do think it's helping.  I didn't use it with my 1st 2 Navelbine tx's, and my numbness kicked up a notch or two.  The L-glutamine seems to be slowing it down.  I did use it when I was getting Taxol, and I think it helped keep it from getting too bad.  I'm also using an Acetyl-L-Carnitine/Alpha Lipoic acid combo, 400 IU vitamin E and a B complex.  I haven't had any pain, just numbness.  My feet aren't bad, my hands are taking a bigger hit, probably because I already had some carpal tunnel issues.  Plus I insist on doing my needlework, which does aggravate it a little.  But hey, a girl's gotta have some fun, right?

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2007 03:58PM mthomp2020 wrote: I haven't really given a lot of thought about swimwear, and I have a swimming pool.  I had a single mastectomy back in August.  I actually have 2 bathing suits that I'll be able to wear still.  I think a lot depends on what type of surgery a woman has and how extensive it was.  The neckline has to be high enough that it won't show scars, and can hold the form/prothesis in place without showing.  I think the age of the woman can also be very important.  A woman in her 30's and 40's will want a different bathing suit than someone in her 50's and 60's.  I think it's a very individual thing. You might want to get in touch with your local American Cancer Association Wellness Community support organization.  They might be able to help you with contacts.  There's probably women who would be glad to give you feedback. What I would like to see addressed is the styling of mastectomy bras.  Most are styles that seem to date from the 50's, with horizontal seams and geared toward a lot of support.  They give you a very conical shape.  I'm 54, but I don't want to look like a grandmother.  I like a rounder, more natural look.  Also, I'm not large - between an A and B cup.  Currently, there's only a few mastectomy bras out there that are like that.

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2008 01:48PM - edited Apr 5, 2008 01:50PM by mthomp2020 It sounds as if they're getting pretty close to Phase III trials with this combo.   I'd love to get in on this trial, but the closest location is a good 2 hours away, and just not doable.  Plus I have to check what my insurance company (Aetna) does regarding trials - don't want to screw up my coverage.  Hopefully when it goes into Phase III, there'll be local locations.  My onc group participates in a lot of trials, so possibly it'll be available there at some point.  Getting this combo could mean not having to do regular chemo for a while, which would be great.  Maybe I could grow and keep my hair for a while!  Plus, no neuropathy side affects!   I've been on just Herceptin for the last 3 treatments, and getting scans on Monday, so hopefully it's keeping me stable.  Fingers crossed for no progression! Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 05:36PM - edited Mar 5, 2008 05:36PM by mthomp2020 I was going to mention Abraxane as well.  It doesn't cause the allergic reaction, and takes half the time to administer.  That kind of reaction to Taxol would be pretty damn scarey! I did 6 Taxol treatments in combo with Herceptin.  Made for a long day!  1/2 hour for pre-meds, 1 1/2 for Herceptin, and 3 hours for the Taxol every 3 weeks.  Never had any reactions to any of it, thank God.  I was able to drive myself home afterwards with no problem.  The Benedryl doesn't make me the least bit sleepy, and the Decadron keeps me going all day!  I get both IV before the chemo.

Posts.Content: mthomp2020 wrote: Just wanted to again thank all you lovely women (especially Binney and kira) for all your wonderful advice, and to give an update. It's no surprise that MLD alone without wrapping did not provide lasting results with my leg lymphedema. So now I'm getting wrapped up past my knee. I'll be going 4 days a week, as the therapist doesn't want to wrap on chemo day - my leg swells that day quite a bit, and she doesn't want to make things worse by stimulating the fluid flow right after chemo. The results from the wrapping have been great. My foot looks normal, and my ankle is considerably better and more flexible/less painful. I can get my foot back in my shoes again when not wrapped. My knee has also improved quite a bit, the thigh is taking a bit longer but is improved. Hopefully after a couple more weeks I'll be able to get a compression garment to wear and I won't have to do my imitation of the Michelin Man. I won't be able to wrap myself due to back issues. After seeing what you have to do to wrap a leg, it's nearly impossible for anyone to do it by themselves even if you're limber, as my therapist admitted. You need a helper, and hubby travels, so night wrapping is a no-go. So we'll look into a night garment if she feels I need it to keep things under control. I'm also seeing a decrease in my hip pain when the swelling is down, so that's a big plus as well. Obviously the lymphedema has had an impact on the tumor in the muscle in my hip, so as the swelling decreases it's putting less pressure on that and really helping. Once again, thank you for your help. It's great having a place like this to come to vent and whine when needed! Marsha Dx 5/21/2007, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2010 01:39PM mthomp2020 wrote: I was stage IV at the get-go, too many liver mets for them to give a number, plus some bone mets.  I did 6 dose-dense Adriamyacin/Cytoxin, then 6 Taxol/Herceptin, and my liver mets were gone, and have been now for 2 years now.  I had a CT scan after 2 tx's, and was already showing shrinkage, so it really worked for me.  I also found the A/C to be very doable.  I just had some queasiness, and of course lost my hair, and my nails were messed up.  I was NED for a year before I came up with bone mets again, but the liver has been fine since then.  So a very effective tx for liver mets. Good luck - hoping you have as much success as the rest of us.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 11:52AM mthomp2020 wrote: Like you, I'm ER/PR-, HER2+.  The combination of Taxol/Herceptin wiped all the lesions out of my liver, and there were enough that they didn't even count them.  So it's a very effective treatment.  Plus there are a number of tx's that are in the pipeline.  So seeing your baby start kindergarten is a very real possibility in this day and age.  So just hang in there and let the chemo do it's thing.  Is the 5cm tumor in your liver or breast?  If you only have 1 in your liver, there's also other options for treating it as well, like Theraspheres, or radiofrequency ablation.  If the chemo doesn't do a totalo job, then you could use one of these other options.
